byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Kirk Johnson from Seattle; Jennifer Medina from Los Angeles; and Patricia Cohen, Maggie Haberman, Noah Remnick and Stephanie Strom from New York.

abstract: Nationwide push to raise minimum wage to $15 per hour is likely to emerge as major issue in 2016 presidential elections dividing Democrats and Republicans along partisan lines; issue has also revealed deep splits among American voters and in how people are compensated for performing same work across United States.
lead_paragraph: What started in New York City as a seemingly quixotic drive for fast-food workers has spread to the point that it has become a significant, and divisive, element in the presidential campaign.

headline.main: Push to Lift Minimum Wage Is Now Serious Business
headline.print_headline: Push to Lift Hourly Pay Is Now Serious Business

snippet: What started in New York City as a seemingly quixotic drive for fast-food workers has spread to the point that it has become a significant, and divisive, element in the presidential campaign.
